entry.title: ICC to open investigation into Duterte’s “war on drugs” | Newsfeed

media:group.media:title: ICC to open investigation into Duterte’s “war on drugs” | Newsfeed
media:group.media:description:
The ICC has authorised a full investigation into alleged crimes against humanity during Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte’s “war on drugs”. Government officials say Duterte will not cooperate.
#Duterte #WaronDrugs #Philippines

entry.title: Afghanistan: Apology ‘not enough’, say survivors of US drone attack in Kabul

media:group.media:title: Afghanistan: Apology ‘not enough’, say survivors of US drone attack in Kabul
media:group.media:description:
U.S military admits a drone strike in Kabul on August killed 10 civilians including children

entry.title: Will sanctions threat end the conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Will sanctions threat end the conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
U.S. president Joe Biden is adding pressure on all sides to end the fighting in Ethiopia's Tigray region. He's signed an executive order threatening new sanctions against the Ethiopian and Eritrean governments, leaders of Ethiopia's Amhara region, and the Tigray People's Liberation Front. While Tigrayan rebels welcomed the announcement, Ethiopia's Prime Minister accused the West of chastising his government. So will the U.S. threat be enough to stop nearly a year of fighting?
Presenter: Imran Khan
Guests: Zelalem Moges - Ethiopian international lawyer
William Davison - Ethiopia Senior Analyst, International Crisis Group
David Shinn - Former U.S. Ambassador to Ethiopia
#TigrayConflict #Ethiopia #USSanctions #AljazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Shining Path founder Abimael Guzman’s remains to be cremated

media:group.media:title: Shining Path founder Abimael Guzman’s remains to be cremated
media:group.media:description:
The remains of the man who founded one of Latin America's most violent rebel groups - the Shining Path - will be cremated. Peru's Congress reached the decision after days of heated debate over concerns that Abimael Guzman's gravesite could become a rallying point for supporters.
Al Jazeera’s Mariana Sanchez reports from Lima.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Peru #AljazeeraEnglish #ShiningPath

entry.title: US threatens new sanctions over conflict in Ethiopia’s Tigray

media:group.media:title: US threatens new sanctions over conflict in Ethiopia’s Tigray
media:group.media:description:
The United States is threatening to impose more sanctions against the warring sides in Ethiopia's Tigray region. A new executive order opens the door to sanctioning members of the Ethiopian and Eritrean governments, the Tigray People's Liberation Front and the Amhara regional government. The conflict has left thousands dead and almost one million people are living in famine-like conditions. Al Jazeera’s Shihab Rattansi reports.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/ #Ethiopia #Tigray #USA #AljazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Qatar restoring coral reefs to help save ecosystem

media:group.media:title: Qatar restoring coral reefs to help save ecosystem
media:group.media:description:
With constant warnings of a climate catastrophe, many governments are struggling to balance economic pressures with the need to protect the environment. Off the coast of Qatar, one project is under way to help the ecosystem, by restoring coral reefs. Al Jazeera’s Jillian Wolf reports.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #CoralReefd #Ecosystem

entry.title: Electric cars: Engineers race to overcome challenges

media:group.media:title: Electric cars: Engineers race to overcome challenges
media:group.media:description:
Electric cars are growing in popularity as the cost of batteries falls and performance increases. But as governments around the world race to slash carbon emissions - engineers are faced with a challenge of improving how far the cars can go. Al Jazeera’s Neave Barker has more from London. - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#ElectricCars #ClimateWarning #ClimateChange

entry.title: Lebanon healthcare crisis: International assistance needed

media:group.media:title: Lebanon healthcare crisis: International assistance needed
media:group.media:description:
The World Health Organization says it will help Lebanon find solutions to its healthcare crisis. Its director general is visiting a week after the formation of a new government. Lebanon is close to bankruptcy, and the country is running short of medical supplies and equipment. Al Jazeera’s Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut, Lebanon
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Lebanon #Healthcare #Healthcarecrisi

entry.title: Algeria’s Abdelaziz Bouteflika dead at age 84

media:group.media:title: Algeria’s Abdelaziz Bouteflika dead at age 84
media:group.media:description:
Algeria's longest-serving president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, has died at the age of 84. He struggled with health issues for years after suffering a stroke. Bouteflika stepped down in 2019 after mass protests rejecting his plan to seek a fifth term. He had been in power for more than two decades. Al Jazeera’s Hashem Ahelbarra looks back at his life.
-Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/ #Algeria #Bouteflika #AlJazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Russia Duma elections: People vote to elect parliamentary representatives

media:group.media:title: Russia Duma elections: People vote to elect parliamentary representatives
media:group.media:description:
Long lines are seen at polling stations across Russia as people vote in parliamentary elections. Many opposition candidates are not on the ballot. But that has not stopped activists from developing an app to guide people on how to vote for independent candidates standing against the government. Bernard Smith reports from Moscow, Russia.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Russia #Duma #ParliamentElections

entry.title: Can a new alliance in Asia-Pacific deter China? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Can a new alliance in Asia-Pacific deter China? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
It's a new military alliance that's got reaction from around the world. China has strongly criticised the U.S., Australia and the UK - after they announced a new deal that will see Canberra get nuclear-powered submarines. But the alliance is pushing back against Beijing. The U.S. Secretaries of State and Defense have met Australian officials and accused China of making expansive and illegal maritime claims. Many see the new alliance in the Asia-Pacific, as another attempt to contain China's influence in the region. Beijing has accused the three powers of having a 'Cold War mentality'. So, will this alliance work? Presenter: Emily Angwin
Guests:
Peter Mathews - Professor of Political Science and International Relations at Cypress College.
Michael Shoebridge - Director of Australian Strategic Policy Institute's Defence, Strategy and National Security program.
Einar Tangen - Political and Economic Affairs Commentator - specialising on China. #MilitaryAlliance #ColdWarMentaly #InsideStory

entry.title: China: Regulating superstars, superfans and big tech | The Listening Post

media:group.media:title: China: Regulating superstars, superfans and big tech | The Listening Post
media:group.media:description:
Xi Jinping's China has embarked on a campaign that could transform the country's technology, entertainment and media industries.
Contributors: Chris Buckley - China correspondent, The New York Times Kaiser Kuo - Host, The Sinica Podcast and editor-at-large, SupChina Bingchun Meng - Associate professor, Department of Media and Communications, LSE Rui Zhong - Program associate, Wilson Center, Kissinger Institute on China and the United States
On our radar A month of Taliban rule in Afghanistan, Meenakshi Ravi and producer Johanna Hoes discuss how the Taliban is already leaving its mark on the country’s news industry despite initial promises to the contrary.
Structures of oppression? Colombia’s falling statues Indigenous Colombians have been toppling statues of European colonisers - challenging how the country’s history is remembered.
Contributors: Didier Chirimuscay - Misak community leader Rodolfo Segovia - President, Colombian Academy of History Amada Carolina Perez - Historian, Javeriana University
00:00 Intro 02:08 China: Regulating superstars, superfans and big tech 11:37 The Taliban and Afghanistan’s news industry 15:19 Colombia’s fallen statues 24:06 Endnote

entry.title: UK supply chain crisis leads to worst food shortages since 1970s

media:group.media:title: UK supply chain crisis leads to worst food shortages since 1970s
media:group.media:description:
The UK is in the grip of a supply chain crisis. It has led to record inflation and the worst shortages of food and basic supplies since the 1970s.
It is complicated by factors like a fall in the number of heavy goods vehicle drivers, Brexit, the climate crisis and a global economy struggling to emerge from the pandemic.
Al Jazeera’s Jonah Hull has more from London.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#UKFoodCrisis #IUKSupplyChain #AljazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Antonio Guterres on Afghanistan: 'Everything went wrong' | Talk to Al Jazeera

media:group.media:title: Antonio Guterres on Afghanistan: 'Everything went wrong' | Talk to Al Jazeera
media:group.media:description:
Since the creation of the United Nations in 1945, there have been nine UN secretaries-general.
The first one, Trygve Lie, famously described his role as “the most impossible job on earth”. But how does the current UN chief, Antonio Guterres, view his position? And does he think the world is heading in the wrong direction?
In the run-up to the UN's 76th general assembly, Secretary-General Antonio Guterres talks to Al Jazeera.

entry.title: Is this the end of China's experiment with capitalism? | Counting the Cost

media:group.media:title: Is this the end of China's experiment with capitalism? | Counting the Cost
media:group.media:description:
Since President Xi Jinping became head of the Communist Party in 2012, he has launched an anti-corruption purge, interned millions of Uighurs and crushed the hopes of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong.
Now, Xi has got his eye on a huge segment of the economy that has powered economic growth in recent years: billionaires, celebrities, property, gaming and technology companies. He argues the side-effect of growth has been inequality and that it is time for “common prosperity”. Iris Pang, the chief economist for greater China at ING Bank, sheds further light on this.
Plus - why collectors are snapping up second-hand watches during lockdowns, according to the Founder and CEO of A Collected Man Silas Walton.
